thread.title: 10 stats to know for the Rutgers-Michigan State game
thread.title_full: 10 stats to know for the Rutgers-Michigan State game

author: Dan Duggan | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: 10 stats to know for the Rutgers-Michigan State game
text:
Comments 
PISCATAWAY â€” Rutgers and Michigan State will square off on Saturday night ( 8 p.m., BTN) at High Point Solutions Stadium. 
Rutgers (2-2) is looking to score a monumental upset, while No. 4 Michigan State (4-0) is trying to remain in the College Football Playoff picture with a win. 
Here's a look at some of the key stats to keep in mind for Saturday's matchup: 
2,158: It's been 2,158 days since Rutgers beat a team ranked in the top 25 (31-0 over No. 23 South Florida on Nov. 12, 2009). Michigan State is ranked No. 4 nationally. The Scarlet Knights last beat a top-5 team in 2007 when they upset second-ranked South Florida. 
73-50: Michigan State has been out-scored 73-50 in the second half of games this season. The Spartans hold a 107-31 advantage over opponents in the first half. 
18-1: Michigan State is 18-1 in its last 19 Big Ten games dating back to late in the 2012 season. The Spartans have won 16 of those games by double figures, and they have won 10 straight Big Ten road games. 
72: Rutgers quarterback Chris Laviano is completing 72 percent of his passes, which ranks fourth nationally. 
PLUS: Michigan State writer expects Spartans to be focused on Rutgers 
22: Michigan State has allowed 22 pass plays of 20-plus yards, which ranks 121st nationally. Laviano has just five completions of 20-plus yards in three starts. He is averaging 11.0 yards per completion, which ranks 88th nationally. 
50: Rutgers is converting 50 percent of its third downs, which ranks first in the Big Ten and 10th nationally. 
2: Michigan State has committed just two turnovers this season. The Spartans' +9 turnover margin ranks fifth nationally. 
16.1: Michigan State's opponents are averaging 16.1 yards per punt return with an 81-yard touchdown. Rutgers' Janarion Grant is averaging 13.6 yards per punt return with a 55-yard touchdown. 
6: Rutgers is down to six healthy scholarship defensive backs. Starting safeties Anthony Cioffi and Davon Jacobs are listed as questionabl e for Saturday's game with upper body injuries. 
35-0: The Spartans were leading 35-0 when they ran a fake field goal in the second half of last year's 45-3 win over Rutgers. The Scarlet Knights have not forgotten about the trick play.
